text: yeah hi everyone Anthony fantano here
the internet's busiest music nerdy and
it's time for a review of the new Nas
album King's disease three this is a
brand new record from Nasty Nas Escobar
who is currently on a creative streak
with a series of albums produced by
in-demand producer hitboy we had the
Grammy award-winning Kings disease one
uh the even harder and more gratifying
follow-up King's disease too and now a
third installment where it looks like
Nas is uh messing around even less as we
have 16 tracks on this thing not a
single feature in sight which if anybody
is going to carry an album who is still
active in hip-hop today it's going to be
Nas of course but still raw dogging a
record like this is uh kind of going
against the grain especially as it's
always presumed that artists who are of
NASA's generation kind of need that
young blood on a record in order to
generate interest and get people
listening to it q21 Savage's recent
comments about how Nas isn't really
relevant he just has a very oil fan base
but no matter what your opinion is on
NASA's current level of popularity it's
clear he doesn't give a [ __ ] he just has
him and hit boy on this record doing
their own thing and that's it energy
wise on this thing Nas continues to
sound revitalized just as he has on the
two previous KD records however it feels
like at this point he's got a lot of the
Nostalgia stuff out of the way this time
around on the track reminisce he even
says and I don't like to reminisce
because what we're doing right now is
really lit and not that it was a bad
thing when he did on previous KD albums
it was great getting NASA's perspective
as a veteran of the game on things new
on things old we even still get bits of
that here on tracks like first time for
example where Nas goes back into the
past and touches down on a lot of things
but especially uh what the feeling was
like the first time listening to NASA's
music so yeah while that element of
NASA's thought process and these KD
records has not gone away entirely it's
still cool to hear him at a point where
he is living a bit more in the present
because his consistency is so good at
this point that he can just kind of be
there's the opener get a reporter where
Hit Boy brings some very classic bumping
drums and piano chops the track is very
hype and glamorous introduction and
essentially Nas brings us a Vibe check
on his current self reflecting on
exploitation within the hip-hop industry
his recent output his storytelling
ability and he even says kd3 goes harder
than the previous two and uh off of the
opener I suppose so far he is correct
and this track is one of many on this
record that really kind of feels like a
Victory lap for Nas uh nothing too
focused or specific really just a
celebration of how well he's doing
creatively and personally I'm on fire is
pretty much the same thing but different
vibe different flow Different
instrumental just as good there is also
legit which is a track of transition
where Nas cleverly reflects on going
legit from street life to music with
lots of witty bars highlighting the
contrast between the two hitboy kills it
with another beat on the song thumb we
have very light drums on this track some
weepy synth leads is a some random chops
from the classic ESG song UFO the whole
instrumental honestly sounds like some
underground MF Doom type [ __ ] but the
slang on this track and the way Nas
describes some of the imagery it gives
the song an amazing sense of place as
it's essentially a tribute to his
stomping grounds and the impact Queens
is even left on his senses as he
describes still being able to like hear
the subway Wheels on the tracks by
comparison the lyrical focus on Michael
and Quincy isn't quite as strong but
it's still a banger pretty much a great
show of the chemistry between Nas and
hip boy I don't know if I would go as
far as to make the Michael and Quincy
comparison as he does in the lyrics but
the hypnotic loops and flows that are
brought to the table on this one are
some of the best on the record on 30
nasflexes his consistency and success
over the years which is all happening
over this huge big lumbering trap beat
something that sounds like it would be
on a Rick Ross record in the early 2010s
it's not bad but far from my favorite
cut on the record as I don't think this
kind of instrumental sees Nas playing to
his strengths uh still he does have
enough versatility to kind of get
through it unscathed with the song hood
to hood the glossy and nostalgic
synthesizers set a soundtrack for a song
where Nas uh hopes four shoots for a lot
of unity from neighborhood to
Neighborhood which is encouraging to see
from an artist who came from an era
where beef was really intense and you
know the various spots in which hip-hop
thrived were kind of segmented
geographically and they each had their
own kind of flavor and Vibe and
sometimes that was cause for friction we
also have the gritty Recession Proof on
this LP which it's funny that Nas
mentioned Superfly at the start of the
track because the instrumental sounds
like it's straight out of a black
exploitation film meanwhile on the
lyrical end Nas essentially lends to The
Listener some advice to invest in
yourself think of your future don't move
sloppily in a way that endangers
yourself the sense of paranoia but also
hope for the future is real and don't
let the title serious interlude fool you
as this is one of the more seriously
focused tracks on the record kind of a
slick cut about a dicey relationship
that Nas was in at one point where he
was uh young and he was the side guy the
hard grew moves but also very lovey
dovey Keys play really well under the
scandalous nature of the story he's
telling here and believe me he tells it
really well once a man twice a child is
a profound reflection on Aging being in
your youth being in your Prime and then
your Twilight years putting you back in
a position of vulnerability as if you
were in your youth again and not only is
it one of the most well-spoken tracks on
the entire record it hits especially
hard from a guy who's in an industry
where you know once you've hit 30 you're
essentially old as dirt which records
like this pretty much prove that is very
much not the case with get light we have
some tasteful Jazz rap with some dance
grooves and some cool sax licks not one
of my favorite tracks on the record
lyrically but even a so-so Nas song on
this LP is pretty great much better than
most of what you're going to find out
there and meanwhile beef is a really
smart concept song where Nas is rapping
from the standpoint of beef itself as if
it were a sentient thing which I think
is maybe the smartest way you could go
about it now with that being said
um loved the vast majority of what is on
this LP uh maybe not super thematic
maybe not the most consistent flow from
track to track to track feels you know
kind of like a potpourri of various cuts
and expressions ideas all still really
well done and consistently performed and
written though you know it's cohesive
enough to the point where it works as an
entire record but still there are some
tracks here that I was not super crazy
about reminisce that I mentioned earlier
I think has a good enough start but the
attempt at I don't know kind of a
lovey-dovey topical switch on the back
end along with like this buttery drill
beat I don't think quite worked there's
also WTF SMH which even though there are
elements of this track that I like I
feel like the uh you know like spelled
out uh LMFAO of course on the song it's
kind of a non-starter and for Nas to be
wrapping these unironically it just
comes off really awkward and there's
also don't shoot which I think is kind
of a weak attempt at a closer it does
start off strong enough with nas
lyrically embracing a pacificity but
then eventually we go into this B switch
that kills a lot of the momentum of the
song Whatever it had up until that point
though I do see the point he is
ultimately trying to make here uh with
going into you know the idea the concept
of King's disease and that being
something that kind of leads uh to these
violent moments and ways that you can
kind of inoculate yourself to it so
again see the point see the message I
know what he's getting at I just feel
like structurally it could have been
woven together in a much more clean
fashion and I don't know considering it
is the final track of the third record
in this Trilogy and you know some great
things do tend to come in threes I I
wonder if this is going to be the final
King's disease album I would hope that
if this is the final song of the final
record in this series like they would
kind of go all out but they didn't uh
really in my opinion I mean at this
point there could be a kd4 I would not
poo poo it Nas and hit boy really do
have something special going for
themselves like I would love to hear
them collaborate again even if it were
just on like you know a different title
series or concept or whatever because
creatively they do seem to gel so Well
which yeah was the case on the two
previous KDs this KD which has some of
the best tracks in the series on it so
far and a very consistent track list and
pretty much everything that was great
about the last two records is also great
about this one but with the exemption of
features it's maybe just a little bit
more no [ __ ] um and and yeah I love
it it was great really good listen I'm
feeling a decent eight on this one
